STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 18, 2024
Lindsey Lassanske
MASON-OCEANA COUNTY DHHS
4081 W POLK RD,
HART, MI, 49420-8177
RE: License#: CP640201336
Dear Lindsey Lassanske:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 6/11/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP640201336
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Lindsey Lassanske
Name of Agency: MASON-OCEANA COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 4081 W POLK RD
HART, MI 49420-8177
Agency Telephone #: 2318737251
Original Issuance Date: 06/01/1990
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
• (6) An agency must document, in the child's
record, within 7 calendar days after placement,
the information specified in R 400.12417(1) and
all the following information:
• (a) All the following child characteristics:

• (iii) Height and weight.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not document youth's height and weight.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
• (6) An agency must document, in the child's
record, within 7 calendar days after placement,
the information specified in R 400.12417(1) and
all the following information:
• (a) All the following child characteristics:
• (iv) Eye color and hair color.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not document youth's eye color and hair
color.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of six foster care files reviewed, and one of two independent living files
reviewed did not have Updated Service Plans completed timely.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
• (3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the agency's
policies and procedures required by this rule.
Two of two independent living files reviewed did not have documentation youth
were provided a copy of the agency's policies and procedures.

CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of two independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the IL
agreement was reviewed with the youth at least once every 90 days as required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change
of placement or no later than three business days after
an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting, retun
from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
h ome/relative placements.
One of six foster care files reviewed, and two of two independent living files
reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/31/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/29/2023
6/9/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/1/2022

FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
b usiness days of the FTM.
Four of six foster care files reviewed, and two of two independent living files
reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not
uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/31/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/29/2023
6/9/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/1/2022
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
w ithin 14 days of the end of the report period.
Two of six foster care files reviewed, and one of two independent living files
reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case service plan within 14
days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/31/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/29/2023
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropraite
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement
agency foster care cases, the local office designee.
Four of six foster care files reviewed and one of two independent living files
reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan (PATP) or the signatures were not obtained timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/31/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/29/2023
6/9/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/1/2022

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must
be docmented in the electronic case management
record.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is
temporary court ward.
• Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
• At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to
each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and accepted
for treatment or services prior to or at the first
schedule appointment while the foster care case
is open, regardless of placement. Subsequent
medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young
adults aged 18 and older).

• YAVFC youth/young adult.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/31/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/29/2023
6/9/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/1/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• DHS 901 form should be uploaded within the same timeframe as the DHS
1105.
• Update IL checklist to include IL policies/procedures and IL agreement
requirements.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency interim inspection was completed on 7/31/2023 and the CAP was
approved on 8/29/2023. The agency was cited for 10 violations, 5 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 5, there was an improvement in individual incidents of
non-compliance within 2 of the violation areas (medical passports and supervisor
approval) and a slight increase in number of individual incidents in the other 3
areas (FTM's, DHS 1105's and PATP's).
In 2022, 13 violations were established, 5 of which were repeated this year. One
of the repeated violations (late USP's) remain close to the same number of
individual incidents of non-compliances. There was improvement in the remaining
4 (FTM's, 1105's, PATP's and medical passports). The agency will need to
establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a
reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency faces barriers regarding medicals and dentals due to a lack
of providers who accept Medicaid as well as client cancellation. The previous CAP
implemented has been effective. The agency developed internal tracking
spreadsheets for licensing as well as FCW/FC supervisor checklists for case
reviews. In addition, supervisors within the agency have been completing more
quarterly case reads. Workers have also taken a more active role in assuring
casework is completed thoroughly and timely. The agency has been able to
maintain foster care staff which has been very beneficial.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisor and coworkers are able to assist as needed.
Staff reported each individual utilizes their own strategy to monitor due dates. Staff
did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: Unlicensed caregiver home has guns that are not secured.
Resolution: Unlicensed caregiver inherited guns after the initial home assessment
was completed. They are old guns that unlicensed caregiver reported he had no
intention of firing and would have as keepsakes. Agency provided trigger locks for
each gun however unlicensed caregiver opted to store the guns at a relative's home.
Safety Alert #2: Licensed foster home is missing a bedroom door. In addition, there
is not a smoke alarm between bedroom and the rest of the home.
Resolution: Agency provided a smoke alarm the day it was discovered they were
missing one. A photo was provided as verification. A new door was installed by the
agency on 5/8/2024. A photo was provided as verification. Due to being a licensed
foster home, the agency also opened a special evaluation.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
______6/11/2024______________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
6/18/2024
_____________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
